translated: The Book of Conditional Relations🔽The Chapter on the Pairs of Doctrinal Terms

analyzed: dhamma anuloma paccanīya  sat paccaya duka ādi

original: Sappaccayaṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca naappaccayo dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.)🔽Hetuyā ekaṁ …pe… avigate ekaṁ.
analyzed: sappaccayam dhammam paṭicca na appaccayaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā  ekam pe avigate eka
translated: With a condition as its support, a non-condition arises by root cause condition. (In brief.)🔽In the case of root cause, there is one. … In the case of non-conflict, there is one.

original: Sappaccayo dhammo naappaccayassa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo.
analyzed: sappaccayaḥ dhammaḥ na appaccayassa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ
translated: A condition as its support, a non-condition by object condition.

original: Appaccayo dhammo naappaccayassa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo. (Saṅkhittaṁ.)
analyzed: appaccayaḥ dhammaḥ na appaccayassa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ
translated: A non-condition as its support, a non-condition by object condition. (In brief.)

original: Hetuyā ekaṁ, ārammaṇe dve, adhipatiyā dve …pe… upanissaye dve …pe… avigate ekaṁ. (Saṅkhataṁ sappaccayasadisaṁ.)
analyzed: hetuyā eka ārammaṇe dve adhipatiyā dve pe upanissaye dve pe avigate eka saṅkhatam sappaccaya sadisa
translated: In the case of root cause, there is one. In the case of object, there are two. In the case of predominance, there are two. … In the case of decisive support, there are two. … In the case of non-conflict, there is one. (The same as with a formed and a condition.)
